translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽The Great Group of Discourses
The Elder Maggasaññaka’s Birth Story
“The disciples of the Buddha Padumuttara
who were living in the forest,🔽having gone out into the great wilderness,
were following along like the blind.
Having remembered the Sambuddha,
the leader Padumuttara,
the sons of that Sage,
having gone out into the great forest,
having descended from their dwellings,
came into the presence of the monks;
I explained the path to them,
and gave them food.
By that deed, O Leader of Men,
best of men, chief of the world,
at the age of seven years
I attained Liberation.🔽The twelve wheel-turning kings,
named Saccaka,
endowed with the seven treasures,
five hundred aeons ago,
the four analytical insights,
I have done the Buddha’s bidding.”🔽Thus the elder Maggasaññaka recited these verses.

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā maggasaññako thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.🔽Maggasaññakattherassāpadānaṁ aṭṭhamaṁ.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā maggasaññakaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati 🔽maggasaññaka therassa apadānam aṭṭhama
translated: The Elder Maggasaññaka’s Birth Story, the eighth.
